name: ZibNameInformation
title: zib NameInformation
description: Name information includes a person's given names, nickname, last name and possibly the partner's last name.
purpose: This HumanName datatype represents the Dutch [zib ('Zorginformatiebouwsteen', i.e. Health and Care Information Model) NameInformation v1.1 (2020)]( https://zibs.nl/wiki/NameInformation-v1.1(2020EN)).
copyright: Copyright and related rights waived via CC0, https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/. This does not apply to information from third parties, for example a medical terminology system. The implementer alone is responsible for identifying and obtaining any necessary licenses or authorizations to utilize third party IP in connection with the specification or otherwise.

element.definition: Name information includes a person's given names, nickname, last name and possibly the partner's last name.
element.comment:
This datatype defines a common basis for expressing all name information around the world, but adds extensions to express Dutch names specifically, according to the [zib NameInformation (v1.1, 2020)](https://zibs.nl/wiki/NameInformation-v1.1(2020EN)). A Dutch name still is a proper FHIR _HumanName_, which means that systems that cannot interpret the extensions will still be able to render and work with this datatype.

To have true compatibility an implementer SHOULD use the core _HumanName_ parts as intended. To have names work for Dutch context, the implementer SHOULD in addition use the extension elements. Furthermore, it is encouraged to provide a representation of the full name in the `HumanName.text` element.

**Separate name parts**

The first addition is that Dutch names make certain name parts separately communicable. These parts are required for use in true Dutch systems when dealing with Dutch names, but may not have value for international systems when information gets sent abroad.

The extension elements cover birth name (NL: achternaam) and partner/spouse name. Both may have a prefix (NL: voorvoegsel). When a person marries, he or she may keep their own name, assume the partner name, append the partner name to their own name, or the other way around. For this reason, there are extensions for marking each part for what it is.

Example: miss Irma Jongeneel marries mister de Haas and assumes the name Irma Jongeneel-de Haas.

* `family` = "Jongeneel-de Haas"
* `given` = "Irma"
* `family.extension:lastName` = "Jongeneel"
* `family.extension:partnerPrefix` = "de "
* `family.extension:partnerLastName` = "Haas"

**The `HumanName.use` element**

The use of element `HumanName.use` is discouraged because the zib model does not contain a corresponding concept. If `.use` is populated, its value SHALL match the semantics of the other elements. To illustrate: if `.use` is set to _official_, it is not expected that the zib concept 'GivenName' (NL: roepnaam) is populated because this is not part of an official name.

If the `.use` element is populated, it is likely that a full name can only be communicated using multiple instances of this profile, one for each purpose of `.use`. Receiving systems SHOULD be able to handle multiple instances of this datatype profile in an instance.

**The zib concept 'titles'**

The zib concept 'titles' for noble and scientific titles cannot be fully mapped to FHIR. Sending systems should make an effort to provide title information in the best way possible using the `.prefix` and `.suffix` elements conform the definition of FHIR. However, if it is not possible to break down the titles properly, it can be communicated as-is using the `.prefix` element . Receiving systems should be resilient for a broader range of information in the `.prefix` element than stated by its definition. See the guidance on the `.prefix` and `.suffix` elements for more information.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a prefix for a familiy name is specified, the family name is expected as well
If the prefix for a partner family name is specified, the partner family name is expected as well
If the name is specified as 'official' then the name is expected to contain only official parts

binding.description: Use ConceptMap NaamgebruikCodelijst-to-HumanNameAssemblyOrder to translate terminology from the functional model to profile terminology in ValueSet HumanNameAssemblyOrder

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comment: This use of this element is discouraged because the zib model does not contain a corresponding concept. If `use` is provided, it SHOULD align with the semantics of the other elements. To illustrate: if `use` is _official_ it is not expected that the zib concept 'GivenName' (NL: roepnaam) is present in the _HumanName_ container because this is not part of an official name.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc.for a current/permanent one

binding.description: The use of a human name.

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: Specifies the entire name as it should be displayed e.g. on an application UI. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating a name SHALL ensure that when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comment: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).

element.short: Voorvoegsel derived from person's own surname
element.definition: The prefix portion (e.g. voorvoegsel) of the family name that is derived from the person's own surname, as distinguished from any portion that is derived from the surname of the person's partner or spouse.
element.comment: An example of a voorvoegsel is the "van" in "Ludwig van Beethoven". Since the voorvoegsel doesn't sort completely alphabetically, it is reasonable to specify it as a separate sub-component.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Portion derived from person's own surname
element.definition: The portion of the family name that is derived from the person's own surname, as distinguished from any portion that is derived from the surname of the person's partner or spouse.
element.comment: If the person's surname has legally changed to become (or incorporate) the surname of the person's partner or spouse, this is the person's surname immediately prior to such change. Often this is the person's "maiden name".

element.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.definition: Given name.
element.comment: To be conformant to the zib for NameInformation, at least the following 'ISO 21090 EN Qualifiers' SHALL be supported: _BR_, _IN_ and _CL_. The qualifier _BR_ maps to the zib concept FirstNames, _IN_ maps to Initials and _CL_ to GivenName.
element.orderMeaning: Given Names appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The person’s official first names.
element.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name parts. Initials may be separated into multiple given names but often aren't due to paractical limitations.  This element is not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.
element.orderMeaning: Given Names appear in the correct order for presenting the name

binding.description: A set of codes each of which specifies a certain subcategory of the name part in addition to the main name part type.

element.definition: Primitive value for string
Noble and scientific titles. These can assist in formulating oral and formal addresing titles.
element.comment:
The zib concept 'titles' is mapped to elements `HumanName.prefix` and `HumanName.suffix`. Semantically this mapping is not complete: the zib uses a single concept that contains all the required information about noble and scientific titles, while FHIR captures the same information in a structured way.

**Export:**

Systems are expected to transform as much as possible to the FHIR datamodel and thereby to be as explicit as possible. Note that in order to mark the type of a prefix, you can use the FHIR standard extension for ISO 21090 EN Qualifiers. Examples include the use of the qualifier _HON_ to indicate honorific prefixes and _AC_ for academic prefixes.

If it is not possible to breakup the zib concept titles to positioned prefixes and suffixes, the prefix element is used to store all information.

**Import:**

Systems need to expect and be resilient for a broader range of information stored in the prefix element than stated by it's definition.
element.orderMeaning: Prefixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Noble and scientific titles. These can assist in formulating oral and formal addresing titles.
element.comment:
The zib concept 'titles' is mapped to elements `HumanName.prefix` and `HumanName.suffix`. Semantically this mapping is not complete: the zib uses a single concept that contains all the required information about noble and scientific titles, while FHIR captures the same information in a structured way.

**Export:**

Systems are expected to transform as much as possible to the FHIR datamodel and thereby to be as explicit as possible. Note that in order to mark the type of a prefix, you can use the FHIR standard extension for ISO 21090 EN Qualifiers. Examples include the use of the qualifier _HON_ to indicate honorific prefixes and _AC_ for academic prefixes.

If it is not possible to breakup the zib concept titles to positioned prefixes and suffixes, the prefix element is used to store all information.

**Import:**

Systems need to expect and be resilient for a broader range of information stored in the prefix element than stated by it's definition.
element.orderMeaning: Suffixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.comment:
A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times").

Period is not used for a duration (a measure of elapsed time). See [Duration](datatypes.html#Duration).
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

element.definition: Name information includes a person's given names, nickname, last name and possibly the partner's last name.
element.comment:
This datatype defines a common basis for expressing all name information around the world, but adds extensions to express Dutch names specifically, according to the [zib NameInformation (v1.1, 2020)](https://zibs.nl/wiki/NameInformation-v1.1(2020EN)). A Dutch name still is a proper FHIR _HumanName_, which means that systems that cannot interpret the extensions will still be able to render and work with this datatype.

To have true compatibility an implementer SHOULD use the core _HumanName_ parts as intended. To have names work for Dutch context, the implementer SHOULD in addition use the extension elements. Furthermore, it is encouraged to provide a representation of the full name in the `HumanName.text` element.

**Separate name parts**

The first addition is that Dutch names make certain name parts separately communicable. These parts are required for use in true Dutch systems when dealing with Dutch names, but may not have value for international systems when information gets sent abroad.

The extension elements cover birth name (NL: achternaam) and partner/spouse name. Both may have a prefix (NL: voorvoegsel). When a person marries, he or she may keep their own name, assume the partner name, append the partner name to their own name, or the other way around. For this reason, there are extensions for marking each part for what it is.

Example: miss Irma Jongeneel marries mister de Haas and assumes the name Irma Jongeneel-de Haas.

* `family` = "Jongeneel-de Haas"
* `given` = "Irma"
* `family.extension:lastName` = "Jongeneel"
* `family.extension:partnerPrefix` = "de "
* `family.extension:partnerLastName` = "Haas"

**The `HumanName.use` element**

The use of element `HumanName.use` is discouraged because the zib model does not contain a corresponding concept. If `.use` is populated, its value SHALL match the semantics of the other elements. To illustrate: if `.use` is set to _official_, it is not expected that the zib concept 'GivenName' (NL: roepnaam) is populated because this is not part of an official name.

If the `.use` element is populated, it is likely that a full name can only be communicated using multiple instances of this profile, one for each purpose of `.use`. Receiving systems SHOULD be able to handle multiple instances of this datatype profile in an instance.

**The zib concept 'titles'**

The zib concept 'titles' for noble and scientific titles cannot be fully mapped to FHIR. Sending systems should make an effort to provide title information in the best way possible using the `.prefix` and `.suffix` elements conform the definition of FHIR. However, if it is not possible to break down the titles properly, it can be communicated as-is using the `.prefix` element . Receiving systems should be resilient for a broader range of information in the `.prefix` element than stated by its definition. See the guidance on the `.prefix` and `.suffix` elements for more information.

constraint.human: If a prefix for a familiy name is specified, the family name is expected as well
If the prefix for a partner family name is specified, the partner family name is expected as well
If the name is specified as 'official' then the name is expected to contain only official parts

element.definition: This concept indicates the last name or order of last names with which the person is to be addressed.

binding.description: Use ConceptMap NaamgebruikCodelijst-to-HumanNameAssemblyOrder to translate terminology from the functional model to profile terminology in ValueSet HumanNameAssemblyOrder

element.comment: This use of this element is discouraged because the zib model does not contain a corresponding concept. If `use` is provided, it SHOULD align with the semantics of the other elements. To illustrate: if `use` is _official_ it is not expected that the zib concept 'GivenName' (NL: roepnaam) is present in the _HumanName_ container because this is not part of an official name.

element.definition: Prefix to the person’s own last name.
The person’s official last name
Prefix to the partner’s last name.
Partner’s official last name.

element.comment: To be conformant to the zib for NameInformation, at least the following 'ISO 21090 EN Qualifiers' SHALL be supported: _BR_, _IN_ and _CL_. The qualifier _BR_ maps to the zib concept FirstNames, _IN_ maps to Initials and _CL_ to GivenName.

element.definition: The person’s official first names.
The person’s initials.
element.comment: Each initial is expected to be delimited by a dot.

element.definition: The name normally used to address the person.
Noble and scientific titles. These can assist in formulating oral and formal addresing titles.
element.comment:
The zib concept 'titles' is mapped to elements `HumanName.prefix` and `HumanName.suffix`. Semantically this mapping is not complete: the zib uses a single concept that contains all the required information about noble and scientific titles, while FHIR captures the same information in a structured way.

**Export:**

Systems are expected to transform as much as possible to the FHIR datamodel and thereby to be as explicit as possible. Note that in order to mark the type of a prefix, you can use the FHIR standard extension for ISO 21090 EN Qualifiers. Examples include the use of the qualifier _HON_ to indicate honorific prefixes and _AC_ for academic prefixes.

If it is not possible to breakup the zib concept titles to positioned prefixes and suffixes, the prefix element is used to store all information.

**Import:**

Systems need to expect and be resilient for a broader range of information stored in the prefix element than stated by it's definition.

element.definition: Noble and scientific titles. These can assist in formulating oral and formal addresing titles.
element.comment:
The zib concept 'titles' is mapped to elements `HumanName.prefix` and `HumanName.suffix`. If it is not possible to breakup the zib concept titles to positioned prefixes and suffixes, the prefix element is used to store all information.
